agentData.mission: Survey the current theoretical and experimental literature connecting discrete-gravity proposals (e.g., causal sets, discrete spectra) to quantum-field-theory-in-curved-spacetime frameworks (pAQFT/AQFT) and analogue platforms (BECs, optical simulators, metamaterials). Produce a concise, referenced inventory of candidate observables (correlators, spectral/dispersion signatures, entanglement measures), existing or proposed measurement protocols, and experimental/astrophysical platforms, highlighting gaps that must be addressed by controlled simulations and statistical inference pipelines.

findings.content: CST now has a concrete perturbative route to cosmology-style observables: Albertini–Dowker–Nasiri–Zalel develop a diagrammatic expansion and generating functionals for interacting scalar QFT on a fixed causal set, explicitly covering Schwinger–Keldysh (in-in) correlators and defining scattering amplitudes with appropriate asymptotics (arXiv:2402.08555).

pAQFT provides a rigorous algebraic/renormalization framework for CST models: Dable-Heath–Fewster–Rejzner–Woods construct observable algebras and states (including discussion of the Sorkin–Johnston state) for discretized operators and use tools like relative Cauchy evolution to quantify background/discreteness sensitivity (arXiv:1908.01973).

Near-term phenomenological handles for discreteness still concentrate in modified propagators/nonlocality: causal-set-derived nonlocal d’Alembertians can imply effective continua of massive modes and altered UV/propagation structure, and are being tested in curved settings (e.g., AdS1+1) and in interacting/continuum effective analyses where a nonlocality scale controls when new behavior becomes important (e.g., JHEP03(2015)036).

BEC analogue-gravity experiments already extract quantum correlations consistent with Hawking-partner entanglement using experimentally accessible density–density two-point correlators across the horizon, but the inferred entanglement is strongly shaped by finite temperature, nonstationarity, finite size, and detector resolution (Nature Phys. 12, 460–464 (2016)).

Optical space–time modulation platforms provide a direct, high-SNR dispersion signature of discretization: discretely stepped space–time modulations yield distinctive tilted features in joint ω–k scattering/diffraction maps and Floquet-like sidebands/band tilts that differ systematically from continuous modulation, measurable via angle-resolved spectroscopy (Nat. Commun. 2025, s41467-025-60159-9; related Floquet/spacetime-crystal literature).
